s.text: From 1991 to 1995, more than 18,000 firms--including 90 percent of the manufacturing sector--were transferred from state to private ownership.

Labor strikes have multiplied in the post-communist era, especially over the last two years.
The threat of further strikes and labor disruptions is another deterrent for investors.
The rationale behind this "shock therapy ": If liberals didn't quickly destroy the Soviet state, Communist Party bosses spouting populist rhetoric would retake power.
At the same time, the central bank has hiked interest rates continuously to check inflation and allay the fears of Western investors, thus discouraging needed business borrowing.

Last year, the private sector generated 70 percent of the country's gross domestic product . Some question the therapeutic value of this policy of rapid privatization, but none dispute the shock.
Yeltsin, in failing health, has lost the confidence of foreign investors.
